cluster_classes.class_description: Narrative stories that depict threats and negative consequences to warn audiences about risks in the world, especially through urban legend motifs.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: cautionary tales and dangers that lurk in the world around them

members.entity_description: Stories intended to warn audiences about risks, dangers, or undesirable behaviors, often by depicting negative consequences.
Various threats, harms, or risks portrayed as lurking in the world in cautionary urban legends.

cluster_classes.class_description: Roles in cautionary urban legends where unfamiliar adults act as potential predators and children are portrayed as vulnerable targets.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: unfamiliar adults depicted as potential predators who attempt to lure children

members.entity_description: Unfamiliar adults depicted as potential predators who attempt to lure children in urban legend stories.
Young people portrayed as vulnerable targets of predatory strangers in cautionary urban legends.

cluster_classes.class_description: Core elements within urban legend narratives, including the tempting object used in the story and the audience who receives the implied warning.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Stories of strangers luring children with candy ... warn listeners about the dangers

members.entity_description: Sweets used as bait by strangers in cautionary tales about child luring.
People who hear these urban legends and receive the implied warnings about danger.

remarks: This class is now empty after splitting its members into more specific classes and can be treated as deprecated or removed in a future cleanup step.

args.new_class_group: Cautionary Urban Legends – Child Luring Scenarios
args.justification: This class defines the overall cautionary urban legend narrative about dangers in the world, specifically in the context of child-luring stories; assigning a focused Class_Group aligns it with related role/element classes.

args.new_class_group: Cautionary Urban Legends – Child Luring Scenarios
args.justification: This class covers predatory strangers and child victims, which are core roles within the same child-luring cautionary urban legends, so it should share the same Class_Group as the overarching narrative class.

splits.name: Bait Objects in Child-Luring Urban Legends
splits.description: Tempting objects (such as candy) used by predators as bait to lure children in cautionary urban legend narratives.

splits.name: Audience of Cautionary Urban Legends
splits.description: Listeners and audiences who receive the implied warnings and moral lessons from cautionary urban legend stories.

args.justification: The original 'Urban Legend Elements' class mixes two distinct concepts—tempting bait objects (candy) and the audience/listeners—so splitting into separate object and audience role classes yields clearer, more coherent categories.

args.new_class_group: Cautionary Urban Legends – Child Luring Scenarios
args.justification: The bait object (candy) is a core element of child-luring cautionary urban legends and should be grouped with the other classes modeling this specific scenario.

args.new_class_group: Cautionary Urban Legends – Child Luring Scenarios
args.justification: Listeners are the audience for the same cautionary urban legends about child-luring, so aligning this audience-role class under the shared Class_Group keeps all narrative participants and elements connected.

args.new_name: Deprecated: Urban Legend Elements (superseded by split classes)
args.new_description: Legacy container class that previously mixed bait objects and audience roles for cautionary urban legends; its members have been moved into more specific split classes.
args.new_class_group: Cautionary Urban Legends – Child Luring Scenarios
args.remark: This class is now empty after splitting its members into more specific classes and can be treated as deprecated or removed in a future cleanup step.
args.justification: After splitting all members into more precise object and audience classes, the original mixed class should be clearly marked as deprecated and aligned to the same Class_Group to avoid future use.
